title: Logosphere - dApp Hackathons
description: Lots of dev time is spent on boilerplate code for off-chain data persistence. Even if a project ships, developing in their ecosystem is hard

f6_assessments.q0:
Building libraries for developers is of utmost importance now. The sooner people can start building the sooner people can start using Cardano.
Getting the dev community to test and build on your product for a prize is a great way to get more devs involved.
f6_assessments.q1: Already committed team actively working on this project. The plan and budget allocation is described in great detail and they have left room for some potential challenges.
f6_assessments.q2: Complete roadmap with possible launch date. The solution they provide will benefit a large community of developers and will make their lives so much easier. They provided sufficient KPIs to measure project progress and success. A part of their budget is set aside for potential challenges.

f6_assessments.q0: Any app or sApp requires persistent data for maintaining the state of the software. There are stored in relational databases traditionally. An example is a valid login for a user. This detail is generally off-chain since it is transient . The proposal aims to build an automated system for handling the abstraction for persistence using fluree. This is likely to reduce the effort of the developers in a substantial manner and will be a definite improvement in the ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal is from a strong team of developers and technology leads with substantial combined experience. The identities and credentials are open and auditable. The capability of the people and the experience is sufficient to ensure that the project is successfully implemented.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal is for 70K for 12 months of development and the rest for the conduct of hackathons to improve adoption. This steep is critical . The objects are clear and measurable. The time frame of 12 months is realistic. The success can also be measured in a quantified manner.

f6_assessments.q0: This teams wants to deliver a TypsScript business domain model generator to allow developers to interface with their off-chain data layer in their smart contracts themselves. They want to use the open source project Flurree (blockchain-backed Data Management Platform for Web3 app) to do so. The addressed problem is clearly (various data persistence frameworks described and the solution fits perfectly into this challenge since it simplifies their work.
f6_assessments.q1: The roadmap presented is a very high standard here in Catalyst. It describes not only what they want to do, but how and why. Behind it is an experienced and talented team that has already demonstrated their capabilities in Catalyst (funded proposal). Also, the budget is broken down in detail. What would be an improvement here is to explain the development costs in a bit more detail to better assess its appropriateness. The project is well thought out and, in my view, ready for deployment. Feasibility is very likely, so now it's up to the community to decide if we want this option in our developer ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q2: The deliverables are clear, the timelines are set, and success is defined in very details, so that the community exactly know, what should happen when. What could be improved here, is to a documentation source, where the community can access the ongoing progress of the project. But overall, I agree, that the community can audit this proposal well.

f6_assessments.q0:
This challenges asks proposers how we can make the Cardano developer experience positive. This proposal aims to improve the cardano developer experience in 2 ways: 1) develop an SDK/API for off-chain state management and 2) hackathons for this software.

Being a developer myself, I can immediately recognize the value of building high level storage APIs and SDKs since they allow developers to focus on providing actual value to the ecosystem instead of (re)building low level primitive tooling. 

The problem statement is clearly articulated but in my opinion the solution statement is vague. It's not clear to me what "Schema generated business domain model" means. However, I understand the rest of the solution statement. I think the communication of the solution statement can be improved.

I think it's likely that this proposal will have a high impact because the team is focusing on hackathons as well as the core software. I think the hackathons will greatly help with adoption and user feedback.

One thing that isn't clear is whether the requested funds will support the team for all 12 months of the roadmap or if more funds will be needed in the future. If the 100k will support all 12 months I think the ROI here will be incredible. 

The KPIs seem well aligned with the goals of the challenge.

I rate this as 4 because some of the technical details of the proposal aren't very clear to me. I would give this a 5 if the team provided some samples of what their SDK would generate. ie: given JSON blob x we would generate typescripts/haskell/marlow types/classes/etc y.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team behind this proposal is very experienced from a technical and business perspective. They have decades of combined experience from the technology industry which means they likely know some best practices for building businesses and writing software. 

They provide a link to a professionally built website which is a very strong positive signal.

I would like to see links to the LinkedIn of each of the members and even their github profiles to get a better sense of their skills.

The budget breakdown is a little unclear. As mentioned in the Impact rating it's not clear if this requested budget will last 12 months or for part of the proposed roadmap.

The proposed timetable is quite reasonable given my experience writing software and I think is very achievable. 

Overall I give this proposal a 4 for feasibility because the professional profiles of the proposers is missing a bit of information and because the budget breakdown is a little unclear.
f6_assessments.q2:
This proposal has done a good job outlining the high level deliverables, the lower level deliverables and the KPIs. That being said, I don't see any numeric goals in the proposal. For example, it would be great if the team set a goal of 10k library downloads or 15 dApps launched by Jan 2023. 

I think the high level deliverables are reasonably well thought out and easy to verify - does the SDK work or not? Can we generate Haskell types from JSON? etc. However, it's hard to measure projected vs actual adoption of the software since there isn't a projection of how much adoption is expected.

Because of these reasons I give this proposal a 4 for auditability. More numeric goals would have gotten this proposal a 5 for auditability.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is absolutely in the right place, as IMO as a dev there's no better way to drive a community forward through hackathons. The impact on the community would be great considering the behemoth of a problem the proposer is trying to solve.
f6_assessments.q1:
Let me start by saying this is one of the best if not the best proposal I've assessed so far.
There's a clear team of people with traceable credentials working on a problem that already has participated in a previous fund, not much more you can ask for concerning a working team.
There's a very clear roadmap for this project which has a unique idea to develop a library in parallel with doing hackathons where devs will be using it and giving constant feedback which is just genius as well as continuous feedback over the period of 12 months.
Another thing I liked which can not be understated is the KPIs the proposers have set for themselves. This is a metric that most proposals still neglect for some reason, but I'm a firm believer that you can't optimize a process that is not measured, and KPIs serve to do exactly that.
I like the diversity and the ambition of this project and I believe the money is worth it, considering the work that will be put in to drive the community forward.
Don't get me wrong, there are lots of great proposals that have some great ideas about ways to push things forward in the right direction, but a lot of them are missing the people with the right credentials and a clear well-thought-out plan.
Overall I love everything about this proposal!
f6_assessments.q2:
As I already mentioned, this is one of the few proposals with actually meaningful KPIs.
A clear timetable and a list of credible people to get things moving. 
The proposer has put into the budget costs for marketing, which would inform all interested parties about the progress of the proposal, so I'd say it's auditable.
Good luck!

solution: Schema generated business domain model w/native temporal state management in the Logosphere L2 sidechain backed by FlureeDB + ***\[HACKATHONS\]***
experience:
Michael Yagi: ex-Tableau

Dmitri Safine: ex-Amazon

Manik Jain: ex - Tata Consulting

\+ 2 Sr. Software Engineers, ex - Fortune 500 companies
